meta.title: What's Your Parenting Era?
meta.description: Discover which phase of your parenting journey you're in — from survival mode to letting go. Find out if you're building foundations, finding your voice, dialed-in, or learning to step back.
meta.intro: Where you are on the parenting arc changes what works. This quiz tells you which era you're in — and what to lean into right now.
meta.subject: you
meta.shareCta: Curious what era you're in? Take the quiz yourself

previewCta.title: Get your complete parenting era profile
previewCta.body: Your primary era, strengths, growth edge, and how you compare across all eras.

previewPromises: Detailed description of your primary era
Your growth edge — one shift that changes the most
How you compare across all eras

communityCta.title: Get scripts and support matched to your era from real parents
communityCta.body: Real scripts, daily support from parents in all phases figuring out what works. We are there with you daily too.

survival.name: The Survival Era
survival.tagline: You're getting through each day — consistency can wait until everyone sleeps three hours straight.
survival.description: You're in triage mode. The question isn't 'what's optimal' — it's 'what gets us to bedtime without casualties.' You know what good parenting looks like in theory. Right now theory lives in a drawer you'll open when you sleep more than four hours.
strengths: You've mastered picking your battles — not philosophically, out of necessity
You don't waste energy on performance parenting or keeping up appearances
You know how to get a kid fed, dressed, and out the door with terrifying efficiency
survival.growthEdge: The shortcuts that worked when you were drowning calcify into patterns you don't love. One tiny routine — same time, same steps, two weeks — gives you surprising breathing room.
survival.encouragement: Survival mode isn't a moral failure. It's what happens when the demands outpace your capacity — which is most of early parenting. The goal right now isn't to optimize, it's to not burn out before they turn four. You're doing the hardest part.
survival.comparativeContext: Most parents cycle through survival mode during major transitions — new baby, illness, job changes, or just particularly feral developmental phases.

finding-voice.name: The Finding My Voice Era
finding-voice.tagline: You're trying approaches, discarding what doesn't fit, and figuring out what kind of parent you are.
finding-voice.description: You're past just surviving but not on autopilot. You're testing the scripts and discovering which ones feel like you and which ones feel like community theater. You're building your parenting identity in real time.
strengths: You're open to trying new approaches instead of white-knuckling what isn't working
You're developing real opinions about what matters to you versus what's just noise
You notice when something works and double down instead of moving to the next shiny thing
finding-voice.growthEdge: Trying everything means committing to nothing long enough to see if it works. Pick one thing — just one — and run it for a full month before deciding if it's you. Consistency beats novelty every time.
finding-voice.encouragement: This is the era where you stop performing someone else's parenting philosophy and start building your own. It's supposed to feel uncertain — you're not following the map anymore, you're drawing it. The parents who skip this phase never figure out what actually works for them.
finding-voice.comparativeContext: Parents typically hit this phase after the fog of early survival lifts but before routines harden — often when kids are 2-5 years old.

dialed-in.name: The Dialed-In Era
dialed-in.tagline: You've got routines that work, you know your kid, and you're not googling at 2 a.m. anymore.
dialed-in.description: You've built a system that keeps the wheels on most days. You know which battles to fight and which to let slide. You can predict meltdowns and head off half of them. You're not looking for the next framework because you know what works.
strengths: You trust your read on your kid more than you trust parenting influencers
Your routines run on muscle memory, which frees up bandwidth for actual parenting
You course-correct small problems before they become big ones
dialed-in.growthEdge: The system that worked at age three can cage you at age six. When something stops working, you resist tweaking it. Stay dialed-in to your kid, not just your routines.
dialed-in.encouragement: This is the sweet spot most parents are chasing. You've earned the confidence that comes with reps — you've done this enough times to know what you're doing. The trick is staying flexible enough to evolve when your kid does, without dismantling what's working.
dialed-in.comparativeContext: Parents in this era often have school-age kids and a few years of parenting under their belt — enough experience to trust their instincts.

letting-go.name: The Letting Go Era
letting-go.tagline: You're learning to step back, trust their competence, and resist swooping in unnecessarily.
letting-go.description: You've built the foundation and taught the skills. Now the work is getting out of the way. Your kid is capable of more than you reflexively give them credit for. The hardest part is watching them struggle without intervening.
strengths: You can tolerate watching them fail at something when you know they'll learn from it
You've stopped doing things for them that they can do for themselves
You give advice when asked and shut up when you're not — most of the time
letting-go.growthEdge: The line between supportive and hovering shifts constantly. You're sometimes still parenting the kid they were instead of who they are now. Check in about what help they actually want.
letting-go.encouragement: Letting go doesn't mean checking out. It means trusting that the work you already did will hold. The parents who can't do this raise kids who either rebel hard or never launch. You're giving them the gift of their own competence.
letting-go.comparativeContext: This phase starts earlier than most parents expect — often around age 7-9 for daily skills, and intensifies through the teen years.

questions.text: It's 7:45 a.m. You need to leave in 10 minutes. Your kid announces they want the blue shirt, which is in the laundry. You:

options.text: Pull the wrinkled blue shirt from the hamper and let them wear it — we're leaving in 10 minutes, not 20
Offer two clean shirts and explain we choose from what's clean, mentally noting to try that 'laundry ownership' thing you read about
Say 'clothes we wear come from the dresser' because this hasn't been an issue in months and you're not re-litigating laundry at 7:45
Ask if they want to grab something from their dresser or rewear yesterday's shirt — they're old enough to solve this themselves

questions.text: Your kid is melting down over something small. Your internal monologue is:

options.text: 'Please just stop so I can finish making lunch and we can get through this day'
'Is this a connection moment or a boundary moment? Let me try that script about naming feelings'
'Ah, they're tired and hungry — snack first, then we'll talk'
'They'll work through it — I'll check in if it escalates but they don't need me to fix every hard feeling'

questions.text: You notice your kid is capable of getting themselves dressed now. You:

options.text: Keep dressing them because mornings are already chaos and this is one less fight
Try a 'you pick the shirt, I'll do the pants' compromise and see if that builds momentum
Add it to the morning routine card and enforce it — they're doing this now
Stop laying out clothes and let them handle it — they'll figure it out or ask for help

questions.text: Another parent casually mentions their toddler is fully potty trained and sleeping through the night. You think:

options.text: 'Cool, mine still wakes up twice and pees in a diaper — we're just trying to survive over here'
'Should I be doing that? Let me look up that potty training method everyone talks about'
'Good for them — we'll tackle that when our kid shows the signs, not when Instagram says it's time'
'Every kid's timeline is different — comparisons are useless'

questions.text: You're trying a new discipline approach. Three days in, it's not working yet. You:

options.text: Abandon it and go back to whatever gets compliance fastest — you don't have bandwidth for experiments right now
Google 'why isn't [method] working' and try the troubleshooting tweaks people suggest
Stick with it for two weeks minimum — you know behavior change takes consistency, and three days proves nothing
Check if the approach makes sense for your kid's age and temperament — tools aren't one-size-fits-all

questions.text: A friend offers to watch your kid so you can have two hours to yourself. You:

options.text: Say yes immediately and maybe tear up a little because you haven't had two kid-free hours in six months
Say yes but spend the whole time wondering if you should be using this time 'better' — working out? Grocery shopping? Therapy?
Say yes because you build regular breaks into your week and this friend is trusted backup
Say yes and don't spend the two hours thinking about your kid because they're fine and you trust yourself to have picked good people

questions.text: Your kid asks for help with something you're pretty sure they can do themselves. You:

options.text: Just do it for them because it's faster and you have 17 other things to finish
Say 'let's try together' because you read that scaffolding independence takes time and repetition
Walk them through it step by step like you've done before — this is a skill they're learning and you're consistent about it
Ask 'what have you tried?' and see if they actually need help or just want you to do it

questions.text: Bedtime is in 10 minutes. Your kid hasn't brushed teeth, picked up toys, or put on pajamas. You:

options.text: Let them sleep in their clothes and skip the teeth tonight — everyone's fried and tomorrow is another day
Try that timer trick you saw on Instagram and see if racing the clock makes it happen
Run the bedtime checklist you've used for months — it takes 10 minutes when you stay on track
Say 'bedtime's in 10 minutes' and let them manage their own checklist — they know what needs to happen
